awd_titl_txt: CEDAR:  Mesospheric Investigation of Gravity Wave and Mountain Wave Activities and Impacts in the Lee Side of the Southern Andes
awd_abstract_narration:
This award would support the deployment, installation, and operations of an Advanced Mesospheric Temperature Mapper (AMTM) at Rio Grande, Argentina (53.8 S, 67.7 W) for a three year period. This instrument would use OH emissions to determine the horizontal distribution of the neutral temperature at 85 km over an extent of 300 km square.  This site already hosts a meteor wind radar and a Boston University all-sky airglow imager. A new Rayleigh lidar will also be deployed at this site in early 2017 by Dr. B. Kaifler from the German Aerospace Center (DLR). The AMTM operates automatically and with the meteor radar, the Rayleigh lidar, and all-sky imager a suite of 4 complementary data sets enabling unprecedented investigations of the characteristics, propagation and dissipation of atmospheric gravity waves would be created. The combined data sets from these instruments would provide a comprehensive set of accurate measurements of mesospheric winds, temperature, and density that would allow the determination of wave propagation direction and speed with high accuracy and cadence. The research site of Rio Grande is located in the southernmost part of South America. This region (South Andes, Drake Passage and Antarctic Peninsula) has been identified as an enormous gravity wave (GW) 'hotspot'. The mountainous terrain and persistent strong tropospheric winds generate a wealth of GWs including intense orographic waves. The research will help understand the GW lifecycle and effects on the middle and upper atmosphere. The propagation of GWs through the MLT region affects the transformation and exchange of mass, momentum, and energy at the altitudes of 80 to 110 km. Finally, the research will contribute substantially to undergraduate student education within the USA and will lead to new research opportunities for expanded international collaboration.

The primary goals of this award are: 
1.) To measure the occurrence and characteristics of MWs propagating into the MLT region in the lee side of the Southern Andes Mountains (one of the most intense source regions for MWs) using simultaneous complementary high-quality instruments (DLR Rayleigh lidar, SAAMER meteor radar and BU all-sky imager),
2.) To estimate the impact of MWs on the upper atmosphere, via momentum deposition and compare with the forcing induced by non-orographic wave observed during the same period,
3.) To compare the new results with previous observations involving similar instrumentations but with different orographic sources and atmospheric backgrounds: DEEPWAVE (New Zealand) and GW LCYCLE 2 (Scandinavia).

por.por_cntn:
This research grant supported unique optical measurements from Rio Grande, Argentina, using an infrared imaging system called an “Advanced Mesospheric Temperature Mapper (AMTM)” that records high-resolution temperature images of a broad-spectrum of atmospheric waves, colloquially termed “gravity waves”. These waves are imaged continuously every night by the AMTM as they propagate through the upper reaches of the Earth’s atmosphere (called the “mesosphere”, at an altitude of about 87 km, or 55 miles). Gravity waves are a naturally occurring atmospheric phenomenon generated by large weather disturbances, such as fronts, storms, or strong winds blowing over high mountain ranges, also named “mountain waves”. They are important as they transfer large amounts of energy and momentum into the upper atmosphere and ionosphere, where they break like waves on a beach, aftecting the background environment.

Rio Grande is in the lee of the Andes Mountains, at the heart of the region considered as the largest mountain wave hotspot on Earth, which makes it an ideal location to study this phenomenon. This site also hosts several other instruments making measurements complementary to the AMTM (radar, lidar, all-sky imager).

Our studies have achieved the primary goals of quantifying mountain wave’s occurrence, signatures and effects, with the following results: (a) First extensive investigation of mesospheric mountain waves covering a complete winter season, (b) their penetration as high as 87 km is relatively common. More than 90 events were detected with the USU imager during a 6-month period in 2018, corresponding to ~25% of the clear sky time, (c) mountain wave occurrence is highly correlated with the semi-diurnal tide, which strongly modulates the total eastward wind, and acts as a gate to the upper atmosphere, (d) the momentum transported by these waves is very large, providing new evidence of their importance and frequent impacts on the upper atmosphere over this part of the Earth.

Further measurements together with future modelling studies will lead to a better understanding of the coupling of wave energy from the tropospheric weather to the Earth’s near space environment.

 


Last Modified: 10/29/2021
Modified by: P-Dominique Pautet
